hero.title: Jellyfish blooms are not rare events. They are a recurring operational risk to coastal power and desalination infrastructure.
hero.subtitle: Seasonal and climate-driven jellyfish swarms repeatedly disrupt seawater intake systems, creating operational instability, maintenance strain, and unplanned shutdown risk.
hero.supportingLine: Across regions and regulatory environments, facilities face the same structural challenge: open-sea intake systems lack a dedicated buffer layer between the marine environment and critical cooling infrastructure. Existing responses are typically reactive, labor-intensive, and activated only after flow degradation has already begun.

problemFraming.title: A structural gap in intake protection
problemFraming.intro: Jellyfish blooms are increasing in frequency and density due to environmental shifts. Yet most coastal facilities still rely on intake designs that directly expose cooling systems to biological loads.

consequences.intro: The result is not only clogging events, but ongoing operational uncertainty:
items: Elevated risk of partial or full intake shutdown
Stress on pumps, filters, and downstream systems

problemFraming.conclusion: The challenge is not the absence of effort, but the absence of a dedicated, upstream mitigation layer designed specifically for biological mass events.

jellyguardPositioning.title: A preventive layer, not another reactive fix
paragraphs: JellyGuard proposes a modular, non-invasive approach that introduces a monitored response layer upstream of seawater intake systems.
Rather than addressing jellyfish only after they reach the intake, the concept focuses on early detection, controlled aggregation, and managed diversion before critical systems are affected.
The approach is designed to complement existing infrastructure, not replace it, and to be evaluated progressively through controlled pilot stages.

marketContext.title: Why This Matters Globally
paragraphs: Thousands of power generation and desalination facilities worldwide operate along coastlines using open-sea water intake systems.
A significant share of these facilities are located in regions with medium to high exposure to jellyfish blooms, particularly in warm and warming seas such as the Mediterranean and the Middle East.
As marine conditions continue to change, biological intake disruptions are becoming a recurring operational consideration rather than an isolated anomaly.

projectStatus.title: Project Status
paragraphs: JellyGuard is currently in an early development phase.
Concept definition and feasibility analysis have been completed, and pilot planning activities are underway.
Field validation is planned, subject to technical alignment, regulatory considerations, and stakeholder readiness.

pilotContext.title: Pilot Context
pilotContext.text: Initial discussions have been initiated with Israel's national electric utility regarding a potential field pilot, subject to technical alignment and required approvals.

evaluationIndicators.title: Evaluation Indicators
paragraphs: Proposed evaluation indicators are intended to support early-stage, quantitative assessment of operational impact, such as reduction in intake disruptions, improved flow stability, and decreased manual intervention.
These indicators are not technical specifications and do not constitute performance guarantees. They are designed to enable informed, comparative evaluation during initial pilot phases.

biomassHandling.title: Biomass Handling
paragraphs: Any handling, processing, or transport of removed biomass is not a condition for system success and is not part of the core mitigation objective.
If examined, it would be considered a separate, optional pilot extension subject to independent scope, space availability, and dedicated budgeting.

ctaEngagement.text: JellyGuard is engaging with infrastructure operators, public innovation bodies, and strategic partners interested in pilot exploration and long-term resilience solutions.

faq.title: Everything You Need to Know
faq.subtitle: Get answers to the most common questions about JellyGuard

items.question: What intake sizes can JellyGuard protect?
items.answer: JellyGuard scales from 0.5m to 15m diameter intakes. Systems are modular and can protect flow rates from 5,000 m³/hr to 500,000 m³/hr. For larger facilities, multiple units work in parallel.

items.question: What power requirements does the system need?
items.answer: Minimal. Standard systems draw 2-8 kW depending on size - 95% less than mechanical screening alternatives. Solar-compatible for remote installations.

items.question: Does it work in all water conditions?
items.answer: Yes. Tested in temperatures 4°C-32°C, salinity 10-40 PSU, and flow velocities 0.3-2.5 m/s. Handles mixed species blooms (jellyfish, salps, ctenophores).

items.question: What materials are used?
items.answer: Marine-grade aluminum frames, HDPE panels, stainless steel fasteners. All non-toxic, corrosion-resistant, designed for 15+ year lifespan in harsh marine environments.

items.question: How is it different from physical screens?
items.answer: Screens trap and kill organisms, require constant cleaning, and create intake blockages. JellyGuard guides organisms away using natural behavior - no contact, no damage, no clogging.

items.question: How long does installation take?
items.answer: Site assessment: 2-3 days. System design: 2-4 weeks. Installation: 5-12 days depending on size. Full commissioning and training: 2 days. Most facilities operational within 8 weeks.

items.question: Can it be installed without shutting down operations?
items.answer: Yes. Modular design allows phased installation during normal maintenance windows. No full shutdown required for most configurations.

items.question: What certifications do installers need?
items.answer: Our certified team handles installation. Local dive team support may be required. We provide full training for your maintenance staff post-installation.

items.question: Is retrofitting existing intakes possible?
items.answer: Absolutely. 85% of installations are retrofits. Works with any intake type: vertical wells, horizontal pipes, culverts, cooling channels. Custom design for each site.

items.question: What is the typical ROI timeline?
items.answer: 18-36 months depending on facility size and current downtime costs. Mediterranean desalination plant achieved ROI in 14 months through eliminated emergency cleanings.

items.question: What is the total cost of ownership vs. alternatives?
items.answer: 5-year TCO is 60% lower than mechanical screening, 75% lower than chemical treatment. No consumables, minimal energy costs, 2-3 service visits per year.

items.question: Are there leasing or financing options?
items.answer: Yes. Full purchase, 3/5-year leases, or performance-based contracts (pay per uptime hour). Flexible terms for municipal and private operators.

items.question: What ongoing costs should we expect?
items.answer: Annual maintenance: $12K-$45K depending on size. Includes 2-3 service visits, remote monitoring, parts replacement. Energy costs: $2K-$8K/year.

items.question: What is the system efficacy rate?
items.answer: 95-98% bloom prevention in field deployments. Independent validation by marine research institutes. Maintains 90%+ efficacy during extreme bloom events (>100 organisms/m³).

items.question: How quickly does it respond to bloom arrivals?
items.answer: Instant. Passive system is always active. Integrated sensors detect blooms 6-12 hours before intake arrival, allowing operational adjustments.

items.question: What happens during maintenance periods?
items.answer: System remains operational during routine checks. Critical maintenance scheduled during low-bloom seasons. Redundant modules allow partial system maintenance without shutdown.

items.question: Is there a performance guarantee?
items.answer: Yes. We guarantee 90% reduction in jellyfish-related downtime or full refund within first year. Performance bond available for large installations.
